item.title: Ticket #1618 (TinyMCE won't accept <del> and <ins> tags) updated
item.dc:creator: schulte
item.description:
​#1674 got me. I just added 

array ('tag' => array(),

to $allowedposttags in kses.php because <tag> was being stripped when posting despite being an Administrator. Maybe I just don't understand unfiltered_html capabilities (see ​#2896), but I thought it should pass it on through normally if my level was high enough (​Filtering Post Content with kses).

item.title: Ticket #1697 (kses needs to strip and add slashes to posts) created
item.dc:creator: donncha
item.description:
kses needs to strip and add slashes to posts: ie: 

function wp_filter_post_kses($data) {
        global $allowedposttags;
        return addslashes( wp_kses(stripslashes( $data ), $allowedposttags) );
}

item.title: Ticket #1696 (WYSIWYG editor stripping tags) created
item.author: joakimlea@…
item.description:
This happens to me on wordpress.com only.

Tags like <a> and <img> gets stripped for all its attributes and ends up in a post like <a>some linktext</a> or <a><img></img></a>

item.title: Ticket #1485 (Don't use trailingslashed IRIs if the user doesn't prefer them) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
I like the idea of putting trailing slash (or not) into the get_*_permastruct() method. Feed permalinks can trivially check for the presence of a trailing slash at the end of the permalink with strrpos: 

if (strrpos($permalink, "/") != strlen($permalink)) { ... }

item.title: Ticket #1695 (link_owner missing!) created
item.dc:creator: donncha
item.description:
The link_owner variable is missing from the links functions: Here's a patch for wp-admin/admin-functions.php to add it back in. (Line number may not match exactly but look for the wp_insert_link() function) 

568c570
<       global $wpdb;
---
>       global $wpdb, $current_user;
584a587
>       $link_owner = $current_user->id;
594a598

item.title: Ticket #1485 (Don't use trailingslashed IRIs if the user doesn't prefer them) updated
item.dc:creator: MathiasBynens
item.description:
The places where we call get_*_permastruct() would assume the structures are already slashed according to user preference and would not call trailingslashit().

I'm not too sure about that. How about trackback and feed IRIs? If we apply the default WP IRI design, we have: 

http://site.com/archives/yyyy/mm/dd/post-slug/trackback/
http://site.com/archives/yyyy/mm/dd/post-slug/feed/

If we'd modify the get_*_permastruct() methods, and if the above user does prefer no trailing slashes, get_permalink() would return http://site.com/archives/yyyy/mm/dd/post-slug, and for instance the trackback address would be generated as http://site.com/archives/yyyy/mm/dd/post-slugtrackback... Right?

In my opinion, this patch is okay; if not the best way to do it.

item.title: Ticket #1528 (Error when submitting newPost using XMLRPC due to incompatible date ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Omegas
item.description:
Version changed

I can confirm that this issue is still present in 1.5.2. Posting through the XML-RPC interface works as long as you don't provide a dateCreated key with the post. The solution presented by chazegh works but isn't very robust since the IXR_Date class constructor is very strict when parsing the date string and the same applies to WP's own iso_8601 functions. The format coming from an XML-RPC client must be exactly YYYYMMDDThh:mm:ss[+-]ZZZZ or everything breaks... I've seen lots of software using YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss[+-]ZZ:ZZ format as "ISO-8601" so I really think WP should be more relaxed when them. Adding conditional '-'s and ':'s in the regexps isn't really that hard after all...

item.title: Ticket #1536 (mysql errors with wp-mail after upgrade to 1.5.1.3 from 1.5.1.2) updated
item.dc:creator: tbhimdi
item.description:
This fix works great for me in 1.5.2 along with the add_filter fix above. 

skippy:
Alternately, add this to wp-mail.php to correctly handle apostrophes in the subject:
$subject = addslashes($subject[0]);
In a stock wp-mail.php, that should replace the contents of line 58.

item.title: Ticket #1693 (Default theme could use a customization interface) created
item.dc:creator: skeltoac
item.description:
AJAX-enabled, gracefully degrading, Kubrick-customizing functions.php with colorpicker.js support. It's a good start.

It looks for images in [themedir]/images/headers/[albumdir]/[filename].(jpg|png|gif) where [albumdir] will be used as the name of the album in the <select> list.

The attached files should be placed like so: /wp-content/themes/default/functions.php /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/colors/black.jpg /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/colors/red.jpg /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/colors/orange.jpg /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/colors/blue_rich.jpg /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/colors/yellow.jpg /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/colors/z_5743.jpg /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/sky/sky01.jpg /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/horizon/horizon01.jpg /wp-content/themes/default/images/headers/horizon/horizon02.jpg

The photos are my original creations and I reserve no rights regarding their use. :-)

item.title: Ticket #1692 (Color Picker needed for theme customization) created
item.dc:creator: skeltoac
item.description: Attached is colorpicker.js, an open-source script that can be used in a theme's admin panel to modify colors. If this could also find its way into a TinyMCE plugin for changing text colors, that would be wonderful. I've already put it to use in wp-content/themes/default/functions.php (my next ticket).

item.title: Ticket #1691 (Missing Hooks for Widget Filters) created
item.dc:creator: GreyGore
item.description:
I'm trying to add a psuedo permissions plugin where I can restrict certain posts from being viewed by certain users based on category (for which I've added a table). This was very, very easy to implement with the main loop by creating a 'posts_join' and 'posts_where'. Unfortunately it's not so easy to filter out results of various other 'widgets' on the blog.

I see that a 'list_cats_exclusions' filter was added to list_cats() with 1.5.2(?), allowing me to filter out the categories. I've patched my 1.5.1.3 install and this works beautifully.

Unfortunately I don't see any methods to filter out get_archives() or get_calendar(), two widgets that would otherwise display post titles and provide links to 'hidden' posts. I don't see any mechanism to plug into, so I would propose adding 4 filters to template-functions-general.php: archives_join, archives_where, calendar_join, calendar_where.

I've also taken a look at get_next_post() and get_previous_post() in template-functions-links.php and I see a place to hook into for excluding categories. Unfortunately, as currently implemented, this functionality doesn't appear to work. Specifically, this is trying to exclude based on post_category in the posts table, which doesn't appear to be set (I'm guessing that when the posts2cat table was added, this field was deprecated).

To 'fix' get_next_post() and get_previous_post() (and add the filtering I need for my plugin), I propose moving the INNER JOIN out of the $in_same_cat block and changing the exclusions to exclude the field "category_id" instead of "post_category". Then after the loop that generates $sql_exclude_cats, add a filter for "next_previous_exclusions".

I've attached a patch for both of the files. Please let me know if you think these changes are possible.

item.title: Ticket #1690 (change to admin/post.php template after post has been created) created
item.dc:creator: bob46802
item.description:
After a post has been created it will just say "Post Site. View Site" with a link to their homepage. I think it would be helpful if it said something like "Your Post has been saved. <link>View Your Site</link> to see the changes, or <link>edit existing posts</link>.

This just gives the user a little more option on what to do next.

Then have it modeled similar on the page-new.php file under wp-admin/ Right now its "Page saved. <link>Manage pages »</link>" It could have a similar to what I suggested above for the post creation.

Both of the post and new page creation confirmations should have a link to the home page, and link to edit existing pages/posts.

This is my first ticket Ive created, I apoligize in advance if I have done something wrong.

item.title: Ticket #1663 (User privilege escalation :: Users can use XSS/XSRF to boost from lvl ...) updated
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description:
@davidhouse: That you trust somebody, doesn't always imply he/she will be true to you as the needle to the pole :)) In two words: trust nobody (at least if you agree that paranoia is a virtue:) ).

@WhiteAcid: Nice description and method. However, I could suggest a little bit easier method to do essentially the same thing. Just include <img src="your.wordpress.host/and/path/wp-admin/users.php?action=promote&id=<your-id-here>&prom=up"/> in the post. Actually you needn't be a level 2 user. If you are level 1 an admin will have to read your draft, and because a preview is shown on edit page, your user level will be up. And up. And up.

The logical question is 'What now?':

  1. Not allowing tags in non-admin posts: Unwanted.
  2. Ensuring all state changes are made by post, not by get request: JavaScript's XMLHttpRequest.
  3. Not allowing other referrals to the promoting action page, except wphost/path/wp-admin/users.php. Could be a temporary cure.

Any other suggestions?

item.title: Ticket #1689 (Changing passwords of other users causes admin to login as the user) updated
item.dc:creator: donncha
item.description: Oops, left in an error_log() :)

item.title: Ticket #1689 (Changing passwords of other users causes admin to login as the user) created
item.dc:creator: donncha
item.description:
When you change the password of a user through user-edit.php the editing user becomes that user. Here's a fix to wp-includes/registration-functions.php: 

77c77,78
<       global $wpdb;
---
>       global $wpdb, $current_user;
>       error_log( "current_user: ". print_r( $current_user, true )."\n", 3, "/tmp/log.txt" );
98,100c99,103
<       if ( isset($plaintext_pass) ) {
<               wp_clearcookie();
<               wp_setcookie($userdata['user_login'], $plaintext_pass);
---
>       if( $current_user->data->ID == $ID ) {
>               if ( isset($plaintext_pass) ) {
>                       wp_clearcookie();
>                       wp_setcookie($userdata['user_login'], $plaintext_pass);
>               }
